conclusion: Determine the amount of heat absorbed by the ideal gas from state A to state C.
State A: P_A = 4 atm, V_A = 1 L, T_A = 127°C (400 K); State C: P_C = 1 atm, V_C = 4 L.
The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.
Convert units: P from atm to Pa, V from L to m³, T from °C to K.
Convert P_A to Pa and V_A to m³ for state A.
Convert T_A to Kelvin: T_A = 127 + 273.15 = 400 K.
Calculate nR using the ideal gas law for state A.
Calculate work done from state A to state B: W_AB = 607.95 J.
Calculate work done from state B to state C: W_BC = 1013.25 J.
Total work done W_AC = W_AB + W_BC = 1621.2 J.
Using the First Law of Thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
Since the process is isothermal, ΔU is zero, so Q = W.
The amount of heat absorbed from state A to state C is Q = 1621.2 J.
